string_data:
Looking at my previous output, I can identify several mistakes in my tagging:

1. I missed tagging the protester messaging from Riposte Alimentaire about campaigning for "social security system of sustainable food"
2. I missed tagging the Extinction Rebellion quote as protester messaging
3. I incorrectly included legal information and general discussion about officials struggling with activists in disruption blocks when these don't describe specific disruption effects

Here is the corrected version:

ID: The-Times_2024-06-02_Attacking-art-should-be
Source: The-Times
Title: #NS Attacking art 'should be criminal offence even if there's no damage' #NE
Subtitle: #NS French culture minister demands law to prosecute activists who target paintings that are behind protective glass #NE
Content: #DS #PH #CS A member of the protest group Riposte Alimentaire with the poster-covered Monet painting Coquelicots (Alt: A young woman in a white shirt with ) #CE
The French culture minister has demanded legal reform to ensure that activists who target artworks protected by glass are punished.Rachida Dati spoke after an environmental activist stuck a poster on the glass case of Coquelicots (Poppy Field) by Claude Monet, the French impressionist, which hangs in Paris's Orsay Museum.The action by Riposte Alimentaire, a French group that #MS campaigns for a "social security system of sustainable food", #ME was the latest in a string of attempts to use important artworks to gain publicity for its cause. The group threw soup on to the glass case of Mona Lisa in the Louvre in January.A source at Orsay Museum said the 1873 work by Monet, which it describes as "one of the world's most famous paintings", was inspected, found to be undamaged and put back on display the same day. #DE #NS Under French law, activists face up to seven years in prison and a fine of €100,000 for "destroying, damaging or deteriorating" a cultural item. But if there is no damage to the work, they often escape prosecution, according to lawyers. #NE
#MS A member of the French branch of Extinction Rebellion told Le Figaro this year: "The actions are not violent and they do not damage the artworks and so they are not criminally punishable." #ME #NS #PH #CS Rachida Dati said such attacks targeted "the most noble aspect of our cohesion — culture" (Alt: A professional woman in a navy blue blazer and shirt walks while carrying a dark folder or tablet. She wears glasses and has shoulder-length brown hair. The setting appears to be outside a building with concrete columns and glass doors visible in the background.) #CE
Dati wants to change the law to ensure protesters no longer go unpunished in such cases."Once again, a cultural institution and an artwork have been targeted by iconoclasts," she said.She said she had asked the justice ministry to implement "a criminal policy adapted to this new form of crime which attacks the most noble aspect of our cohesion — culture". #NE #DS Officials in France and other European countries have struggled to deal with activists who target protected cultural items without causing damage. In the Netherlands, two Just Stop Oil campaigners received jail sentences for gluing themselves to the glass protection of Girl with the Pearl Earring, though this was later overturned. Similar protests have targeted historical documents including the Magna Carta. #DE
#DS #PH #CS Just Stop Oil protesters in their eighties target Magna Carta (Alt: Two elderly protesters wearing glasses stand indoors holding signs. One wears a white ) #CE #DE
